page.title: 02Landscape
page.content: The Urban Landscape of Crail Crail is a town of ancient stone-built houses with red pantile roofs, crow-stepped gables and that appearance of solid endurance which characterises traditionally Scottish architecture. Its harbour is a never-ending source of interest. It has an unspoiled coastline of rocks and sandy beaches. The land around Crail has trees only round the farm houses and the town, asit is mostly agricultural. The people in Crail keep beautiful gardens, some of them called 'Lang Riggs' because of their length. There are several historic buildings like the Town House, the Doocot and the Church, and many old houses with outside stairs can be found on the way down the steep streets leading to the harbour.
